title: How can a teacher recognize a plagiarized essay? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: How can a teacher recognize a plagiarized essay? A: There are two things that usually set off an alarm bell for me: (1) The student is writing beautiful and authoritative prose citing arcane sources, and then is suddenly writing like a college sophomore (or high school junior). This is followed by more scholarly prose. It is the “real you” sentences that link the plagiarized paragraphs that are the giveaway. (2) The references are the second place I look for hints of plagiarism. If for example, the essay is about knife violence in the UK. and the most recent reference is say, two years old, it is probably copied from the internet, an old text book or article, or paper from the fraternity files. In addition: If a sentence or paragraph seems too familiar, I Google it.Software such as Turnitin is a good check—as well as paraphrasing software.Finally, if I am suspicious, but lack proof, I resort to the ancient and secret technique known only by its Latin name, defraudat capiens. Defraudat capiens is entrusted only to the wisest teachers of teachers of each generation when they graduate and are inducted into the ancient order of Prudens et Magistra. Teachers are bound by blood oath or pinky promise by spitting never to reveal this ancient wisdom said to have been developed by Socrates himself. So if you are a lazy kid trying to get information on safe ways to cheat on essays, don’t even try. Your Teachers know how to catch you, and you will be punished.

Look for sophisticated vocabulary choices, sentence structure, and other clues. If you suspect that an essay is plagiarized, sit down with the student to talk. Be pleasant. Ask them to tell you about the essay. Where did the ideas come from? What parts were easy to write? Difficult? What strategies helped them? If they’re at a loss to answer your questions, they’ll soon admit it’s not their own work. But if you’re teaching essay writing as a process, your students won’t be able to use an essay service. You can prevent the whole problem. You’re teaching students how to write essays, right? So they should be bringing each stage of the essay to class: freewriting, outline, rough draft, revisions, and so on. Pair students up or put them into groups to discuss and revise their work. Give them checklists. Walk around, pick up their work and look at it. Whenever possible, make sure your assignments require critical thinking. If you’re really teaching essay writing and requiring students to talk about how they’re working through each step - sharing their work - helping one another - getting feedback from you - they’ll be forced to do their own work. The way essay writing has traditionally been taught is crazy, in my opinion. The teacher announces the topic and never says another word about it. Students are lost. They write weak essays - or get someone else to write the essay for them. The weak essays require hours of correcting from the teacher - who already knows how to write well. Why not require the students to do the corrections? “They can’t” is the teacher’s response. Well, isn’t it time for them to start learning? What are they going to do on the job later on, when there’s no teacher standing behind them to edit their work?

A teacher can often detect plagiarism just by consistency. If the style and syntax change, especially if they suddenly and inexplicably become better than the rest of the text, one can suspect plagiarism. A really good plagiarist could work around this with hard work, but but that defeats the purpose of most plagiarists, which is to get by with less work. In the old days, it would be difficult to prove plagiarism unless the writer copied something that the teacher remembered. But today it is relatively easy because of plagiarism-detecting software, such as Turnitin, that can find obscure text (and just about any text).

Two common ways teachers detect academic plagiarism: LogicExperienced teachers can easily recognize cheaters in class. How? Imagine a mediocre student who suddenly starts to write like Shakespeare or two best friends who accidentally wrote similar papers. It seems suspicious, doesn’t it? Try to avoid such coincidences. Plagiarism softwareThere are plenty of online tools that help teachers catch dishonest students when plagiarism is not so obvious. Plagiarism detection services like Unplag (https://unplag.com/) provide an accurate pagiarism report and confirm/decline teacher’s apprehension. It goes without saying that the latter method is more relaible and well-grounded.

There are different ways to detect plagiarism: one of them is to use specific software that analyses your text and gives back a report on the amount of original and copied text you’ve used. Another option is using your own experience: teachers have seen plenty of papers that were taken from online sources, they’ve probably learn’t most of them and can detect plagiarism from the first sight. Also, it is easy to notice when a student have been submitting papers written in one way and then gives a paper with a writing style that totally differs from previous works (of course, you can improve one, but again, it can easily be detected if you’ve been using what someone else told or not).

Only plagiarism checkers may help. You can use A) Free software B) Paid software C) Partly free software. I highly do not recommend using absolutely free plagiarism checkers - it’s a waste of your time. There are no good and absolutely free checker. There are good paid checkers, but you will spend much cash on finding the good one. So the best solution - use partly free plagiarism checkers. For example, Free Plagiarism Checker Plagramme allows teachers to use their software for free, but they hope you to inform your students that you prefer them. All their system is built, that teacher may use software for free , but you are gently asked to inform your students about plagramme.

I’m studying with the Open University. They provide a whole section on plagiarism and how to avoid it, plus a warning that when you submit an assignment, a web search is made, presumably for key phrases, to confirm that you aren’t plagiarising work.
